sngdate.caldate: Upper North Thompson River Watershed Group (UNTH): 1998-9-8

srcinfo.srccontr:
1. The watershed and the watershed group boundaries of the BC Watershed Atlas (1:50k) comprise the DA polygon's boundary.
The watersheds of the BC Watershed Atlas (1:50k) are organized as watershed groups. Each watershed group contains 3rd-order or higher watersheds. Each watershed boundaries were determined solely upon hydrologic and topographic features. They are defined along natural hydrologic breaks based on land surface, surface water flow, and hydrographic features. Therefore, all the upstream watersheds and the watershed groups from the gauging station can be used to comprise the DA polygon.
2. The stream features of the BC Watershed Atlas (1:50k) along with the contour features of the CanVec dataset were used as the backdrop to determine the heights of land, rivers and streams etc, respectively. The terminal downstream arc of the DA polygon was drawn along the heights of land.

citeinfo.title: CanVec, Canada
citeinfo.origin: Government of Canada, Natural Resources Canada, Earth Sciences Sector, Mapping Information Branch, Centre for Topographic Information - Sherbrooke

srcinfo.srccontr: The contour features of the source data along with the stream features of the BC Watershed Atlas (1:50k) dataset were used as the backdrop to determine the heights of land, rivers and streams etc, respectively. The terminal downstream arc of the DA polygon was drawn along the heights of land.

cntperp.cntorg: Meteorological Service of Canada, Environment Canada

procstep.procdesc:
This product was created through the following steps: (Note: all the features were projected to BC Albers Equal Area Conic, NAD83 to do the process.)
Step 1. Stage 1: ArcView GIS 3.3 stage: Used BC Watershed Atlas (1:50k) dataset as input to run a pre-developed extension "Delineation Tool" in ArcView GIS 3.3 to automatcally select and accumulate all the upstream watershed and watershed group polygons that flow to the gauging station. (The watershed where the station resides was also automatically selected.)
Stage 2: ArcGIS 9.3.1 stage: 1. Loaded the accumulated watershed/watershed group polygons into ArcGIS (ArcMap) 9.3.1. 2. Defined the projection of them as BC Albers Equal Area Conic, NAD83. 3. Loaded the BC Watershed Atlas (1:50k) watershed, watershed group and stream data into ArcMap. 4. Dissolved the accumulated upstream watershed/watershed group polygons from the gauge as one polygon. 5. Loaded the 1:50k CanVec contour data to ArcMap. 6. Used the contour features on the 1:50k CanVec and the streams of the BC Watershed Atlas (1:50k) dataset as the backdrop to determine the heights of land and rivers/streams etc, respectively. Then manually drew the terminal downstream arc of the DA polygon such that the arc should be along the heights of land and cross the dissolved polygon. 7. Split the dissolved polygon into two polygons by using the terminal downstream arc. Then kept the polygon which flows to the gauging station and removed another one.
This remained polygon was the upstream DA polygon for the gauging station.

attracc.attraccr:
1. The watershed and the watershed group boundaries of the BC Watershed Atlas are used as this DA polygon boundary. 2. The terminal downstream boundary line is manually drawn based on the water features of BC Watershed Atlas dataset and contour features of the CanVec dataset.
There is no issue encountered during the delineation.

report.measDesc: 1. The watershed and the watershed group boundaries of the BC Watershed Atlas are used as this DA polygon boundary. 2. The terminal downstream boundary line is manually drawn based on the water features of BC Watershed Atlas dataset and contour features of the CanVec dataset. There is no issue encountered during the delineation.

prcStep.stepDesc: This product was created through the following steps: (Note: all the features were projected to BC Albers Equal Area Conic, NAD83 to do the process.) Step 1. Stage 1: ArcView GIS 3.3 stage: Used BC Watershed Atlas (1:50k) dataset as input to run a pre-developed extension "Delineation Tool" in ArcView GIS 3.3 to automatcally select and accumulate all the upstream watershed and watershed group polygons that flow to the gauging station. (The watershed where the station resides was also automatically selected.) Stage 2: ArcGIS 9.3.1 stage: 1. Loaded the accumulated watershed/watershed group polygons into ArcGIS (ArcMap) 9.3.1. 2. Defined the projection of them as BC Albers Equal Area Conic, NAD83. 3. Loaded the BC Watershed Atlas (1:50k) watershed, watershed group and stream data into ArcMap. 4. Dissolved the accumulated upstream watershed/watershed group polygons from the gauge as one polygon. 5. Loaded the 1:50k CanVec contour data to ArcMap. 6. Used the contour features on the 1:50k CanVec and the streams of the BC Watershed Atlas (1:50k) dataset as the backdrop to determine the heights of land and rivers/streams etc, respectively. Then manually drew the terminal downstream arc of the DA polygon such that the arc should be along the heights of land and cross the dissolved polygon. 7. Split the dissolved polygon into two polygons by using the terminal downstream arc. Then kept the polygon which flows to the gauging station and removed another one. This remained polygon was the upstream DA polygon for the gauging station.

stepProc.rpOrgName: Meteorological Service of Canada, Environment Canada

dataSource.srcDesc: 1. The watershed and the watershed group boundaries of the BC Watershed Atlas (1:50k) comprise the DA polygon's boundary. The watersheds of the BC Watershed Atlas (1:50k) are organized as watershed groups. Each watershed group contains 3rd-order or higher watersheds. Each watershed boundaries were determined solely upon hydrologic and topographic features. They are defined along natural hydrologic breaks based on land surface, surface water flow, and hydrographic features. Therefore, all the upstream watersheds and the watershed groups from the gauging station can be used to comprise the DA polygon. 2. The stream features of the BC Watershed Atlas (1:50k) along with the contour features of the CanVec dataset were used as the backdrop to determine the heights of land, rivers and streams etc, respectively. The terminal downstream arc of the DA polygon was drawn along the heights of land.

The contour features of the source data along with the stream features of the BC Watershed Atlas (1:50k) dataset were used as the backdrop to determine the heights of land, rivers and streams etc, respectively. The terminal downstream arc of the DA polygon was drawn along the heights of land.
